canvases.label: Letter from Butler to Douglas, f.13v

metadata.value: Page 2 of 3. A letter to Captain Charles Douglas, commander of the St. Lawrence fleet, from Butler, who was quartered on the ship Inflexible during the Battle of Valcour Island on Lake Champlain from 11-13 October 1766. Butler recounts the movements and action of the Inflexible, as well as the Maria, the Carleton, a gondola, a radeau, and 17 gun boats. On the morning of the 11th, the British fleet encountered the American fleet by Valcour Island, and specific reference is made throughout the account to the schooner Royal Savage, which was run aground and bombarded. The Inflexible is described as having considerable firepower. On the British side, the Carleton was badly damaged, and three British gun boats were lost. After the day of naval fighting, the British fleet awoke on the morning of the 12th to find the Americans were escaping to the south. Chase was given and fighting resumed on the 13th, when the wind changed north and disadvantaged the American fleet's flight. The battle ended in favour of the British, due in part to the arrival of the slower but very powerful Inflexible. Butler concludes his letter by stating that he will “leave it to any one to judge, how much the Success of both Engagements was owing to the effects of the heavy metal of the Inflexible, And moreover to her formidable Appearance.”
